description: From Middle English rescouen, from Old French rescoure, rescurre, rescorre; from Latin prefix re- (“re-”) + excutere, present active infinitive of excutiō (“I shake or drive out”), from ex (“out”) + quatiō (“I shake”).

entries.meaning: An act or episode of rescuing, saving.
The forcible ending of a siege; liberation from similar military peril.
examples: The rescue of Jerusalem was the original motive of the Crusaders

entries.meaning: A special airliner flight to bring home passengers who are stranded.

examples: The dog was a rescue with some behavior issues.

verbs.description: rescue (third-person singular simple present rescues, present participle rescuing, simple past and past participle rescued) (transitive)

entries.meaning: To save from any violence, danger or evil.
examples: The well-trained team rescued everyone after the avalanche.

entries.meaning: To free or liberate from confinement or other physical restraint.
examples: to rescue a prisoner from the enemy.

entries.meaning: To deliver by arms, notably from a siege.
(figuratively) To remove or withdraw from a state of exposure to evil and sin.
examples: Traditionally missionaries aim to rescue many ignorant heathen souls.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To achieve something positive under difficult conditions.
